awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  CMOS-Integration of Isolated AC/DC conversion with Integrated Powerline Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that it will revolutionize AC-DC convertors that are present in nearly all existing and future residential and commercial electronic devices.  Reduced convertor complexity and increased power efficiency will result in extreme cost savings for both the manufacturers of these devices as well as the end consumers, enabling adoption to all corners of society.  This dramatically different integrated convertor will also bring powerline communications into these electronic devices, a game changer that will enable electronics developers to add intelligence to their products across numerous markets such as home and office IoT devices, AC powered medium-wattage (~5W) electronics, power-over-ethernet, and smart LED lighting.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will create an alternative integrated AC-DC converter architecture.  Existing converters have numerous bulky, expensive, and unreliable discrete magnetic components that will be replaced with this integrated circuit (IC) based solution.  The result of this project will be a reduced footprint, reduced BOM count, efficient converter for medium wattage (~5W) electronic loads.  This project will additionally support low wattage loads (<1W) with an even smaller footprint and even lower BOM count, showcasing the scalability of this technology which is not an option with existing fly-back AC-DC convertor solutions.  Validation of the Phase I IC-based converter performance will provide a foundation for Phase II, and incorporation into powerline communications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project successfully demonstrated a high voltage (115 V), high efficiency (82%) DC-DC power convertor with an integrated circuit (IC) based solution, which serves as a technology platform for an eventual IC-based AC-DC convertor targeted for mass production in the Type-A LED bulb driver market. 

Industry standard design software was used to design, simulate, and layout both IC revisions.  The combination of high voltage and fast switching transients required the development of new design and simulation methods to enable simulator convergence and to meet the difficult efficiency specifications.  After release to the foundry for manufacturing, a specialized test printed circuit board (PCB) was also designed and fabricated.  A small laboratory was built and when tested, the IC was a first pass success, demonstrating full functionality and proper DC conversion ratios at high efficiency when delivering up to 5W of load power.

After the first IC was tested, engagement began with the first viable high-volume customer which changed the specifications to meet the requirements for a specific LED bulb market. A revised IC was then designed and released to the foundry for fabrication.  Simulations show that it can handle up to 200V input, has additional DC-DC division ratio options, and can deliver 9W of power with 92% efficiency.

When the IC is combined with an input rectification stage, the complete AC-DC convertor solution has the potential to revolutionize existing low to medium power convertors because the solution is IC based and does not rely on bulky and expensive magnetic components.  There is an industry momentum to maintain the status quo using these magnetic components, but this is a more cost effective, smaller footprint, and environmentally friendly solution. The potential broader impact of this technology on society is enormous because of its’ effect on the convertor supply chain, which has been amplified by the recent worldwide shortage of electronic components.  Because there are so many power convertors worldwide and this solution requires far fewer components, the ripple effects on the electronics supply chain and related academic research programs would be significant.

The U.S. Department of Energy’s (DOE) 2020 study showed that, as of 2018, LED penetration was 29.8% for indoor lighting and 51.4% for outdoor lighting in the United States. They also forecast that LED lighting will represent 84% of all lighting sales by 2035, of which 12% will be made possible by LED lighting with communication capabilities. Their study also showed that in 2016, 2048 million units of Type-A LED Drivers, valued at 6.16 USD Billion, were shipping annually and grew (in terms of volume) at a CAGR of 56.4% in the period from 2016 to 2022. At these volumes, any marginal improvements in efficiency and/or component count will have a significant impact on worldwide lighting energy demands and production waste.

Currently, LED Driver technology is outdated and its’ deployment occurs mostly in Southeast Asia and China. This novel convertor solution enables future development to occur in the United States. Since it is a more sophisticated IC based solution and is a building block for smart power convertor solutions, it will promote activity within related academic fields, foster intellectual growth in power electronics, and spawn offshoot technologies.  The possibilities for building upon this base power convertor technology are vast. 

NSF sponsored training webinars and education resources enabled connections with many prospective customers and market thought leaders, which led to securing two near-term business opportunities and a much deeper understanding of the far-reaching potential impact of this power conversion technology.

Modified by: Saroj Rout
